docs.lead_paragraph: Health officials say a baby born in a Hawaii hospital is the first in the U.S. with a birth defect linked to the Zika virus, a tropical illness currently found in Latin American and Caribbean countries.

headline.main: Q&A: Hawaii Baby Born With Defect Linked to Zika Virus
headline.print_headline: Q&A: Hawaii Baby Born With Defect Linked to Zika Virus

docs.snippet: Health officials say a baby born in a Hawaii hospital is the first in the U.S. with a birth defect linked to the Zika virus, a tropical illness currently found in Latin American and Caribbean countries.

docs.lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — Health officials say a baby born in a Hawaii hospital is the first in the United States with a birth defect linked to the Zika virus, a tropical illness currently found in Latin American and Caribbean countries. The Hawaii state Department of Health said the baby's mother likely contracted the disease while living in Brazil last year and passed it on while her child was in the womb. Here are some questions and answers about the case.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. health officials issued new guidance Tuesday for doctors whose pregnant patients may have traveled to regions with a tropical illness linked to birth defects.

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Tuesday issued guidelines for doctors caring for pregnant women who might have been exposed to Zika virus, a mosquito-borne infection that can cause brain damage in a developing fetus.

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court refused on Tuesday to revive an Arkansas law that would have banned abortions after the 12th week of pregnancy if doctors can detect a fetal heartbeat.

headline.main: US Supreme Court Rejects Arkansas Bid to Revive Abortion Law
headline.print_headline: US Supreme Court Rejects Arkansas Bid to Revive Abortion Law

docs.snippet: The U.S. Supreme Court refused on Tuesday to revive an Arkansas law that would have banned abortions after the 12th week of pregnancy if doctors can detect a fetal heartbeat.

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court, which is due to hear arguments in March in an important abortion case from Texas, on Tuesday rejected a bid by Arkansas to revive a state law blocked by a lower court that had banned abortions after 12 weeks of pregnancy.

headline.main: U.S. Justices Reject Arkansas Bid to Revive Abortion Law
headline.print_headline: U.S. Justices Reject Arkansas Bid to Revive Abortion Law

docs.snippet: The U.S. Supreme Court, which is due to hear arguments in March in an important abortion case from Texas, on Tuesday rejected a bid by Arkansas to revive a state law blocked by a lower court that had banned abortions after 12 weeks of pregnancy.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jamaica's health minister is advising women to delay plans to become pregnant for the next six to 12 months due to the mosquito-borne Zika virus.

headline.main: Jamaica Advises Women to Delay Pregnancy Due to Zika Virus
headline.print_headline: Jamaica Advises Women to Delay Pregnancy Due to Zika Virus

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study suggests that out-of-hospital births could carry slightly higher risks.

headline.main: Weighing the Risks of Home Births
headline.print_headline: Weighing the Risks of Home Births

docs.abstract: Editorial notes study in the New England Journal of Medicine showing home births present slightly more risk to mother and child than hospital births; holds study's conclusions are potentially more reliable than those of previous studies showing that home births are equally safe.
docs.snippet: A new study suggests that out-of-hospital births could carry slightly higher risks.

docs.lead_paragraph: After failing to comply with a 2004 lawsuit, Mississippi is trying to avoid becoming the first state to have its child welfare system put in receivership.

headline.main: Mississippi Fights to Keep Control of Its Beleaguered Child Welfare System
headline.print_headline: Mississippi Fights to Keep Control of Its Child Welfare System

docs.abstract: Mississippi is fighting to avoid becoming first state to have its child welfare system put in receivership and outside group hired to run it, following years of dysfunction and failure to repair ailing system; state's Division of Family and Children's Services was subject of 2004 class-action lawsuit for failing to protect children, but has admitted it never complied with requirements of settlements made in 2008 and later.
docs.snippet: After failing to comply with a 2004 lawsuit, Mississippi is trying to avoid becoming the first state to have its child welfare system put in receivership.

byline.contributor: Emily Palmer reported from Waveland, and Campbell Robertson from New Orleans
